original: 8. Akusalacchedanapañha
translated: The Questions about the Cutting off of the Unwholesome

original: “Bhante nāgasena, tathāgato sabbaṁ akusalaṁ jhāpetvā sabbaññutaṁ patto, udāhu sāvasese akusale sabbaññutaṁ patto”ti?
analyzed: bhante nāgasena tathāgataḥ sabbam akusalam jhāpetvā sabbaññu tam patto udāhu sa avasese akusale sabbaññu tam patto ti
translated: “Is it because he had burned up all the unwholesome states that the Tathāgata attained omniscience, or did he attain omniscience while there was still some unwholesome left?”

original: “Sabbaṁ, mahārāja, akusalaṁ jhāpetvā bhagavā sabbaññutaṁ patto, natthi bhagavato sesakaṁ akusalan”ti.
analyzed: sabba mahā rāja akusalam jhāpetvā bhagavā sabbaññutam pattaḥ natthi bhagavato sesakam akusalanti
translated: “Great king, the Blessed One attained omniscience after he had burned up all the unwholesome states. There is no unwholesome left in the Blessed One.”

original: “Kiṁ pana, bhante, dukkhā vedanā tathāgatassa kāye uppannapubbā”ti?
analyzed: kim pana bhante dukkhā vedanā tathāgatassa kāye uppanna pubbā ati
translated: “But, revered sir, did painful feelings ever arise in the Tathāgata’s body?”🔽“Yes, great king, in Rājagaha a stone splinter pierced the Blessed One’s foot,

original: “Āma, mahārāja, rājagahe bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato, lohitapakkhandikābādho
analyzed: āma mahā rāja rājagahe bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khataḥ lohita pakkhandika ābādho
translated: and he suffered from dysentery.

original: uppanno, kāye abhisanne jīvakena vireko kārito, vātābādhe uppanne upaṭṭhākena therena
analyzed: uppanno kāye abhisanne jīvakena vireko kārito vāta ābādhe uppanne upaṭṭhākena therena
translated: When he was afflicted with wind in the bowels, his attendant, the elder,

original: uṇhodakaṁ pariyiṭṭhan”ti.
analyzed: uṇha udakam pariyiṭṭhanti
translated: had to get hot water for him.”

original: “Yadi, bhante nāgasena, tathāgato sabbaṁ akusalaṁ jhāpetvā sabbaññutaṁ patto, tena
analyzed: yadi bhante nāgasena tathāgataḥ sabbam akusalam jhāpetvā sabbaññu tam pattaḥ tena
translated: “If, revered Nāgasena, the Tathāgata attained omniscience after he had burned up all the unwholesome states, then he did not attain omniscience after he had burned up all the unwholesome states.

original: hi bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato, lohitapakkhandikā ca ābādho uppannoti yaṁ vacanaṁ, taṁ micchā.
analyzed: hi bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khataḥ lohitapakkhandikā ca ābādhaḥ uppannoti yam tam micchā
translated: that the Blessed One’s foot was cut by a stone splinter and that he had a pain in the side due to a bile-disorder, is wrong.

original: Yadi tathāgatassa pādo sakalikāya khato, lohitapakkhandikā ca ābādho uppanno, tena hi tathāgato sabbaṁ akusalaṁ jhāpetvā sabbaññutaṁ pattoti tampi vacanaṁ micchā.
analyzed: yadi tathāgatassa pādaḥ sakalikāya khataḥ lohitapakkhandikā ca ābādhaḥ uppanno tena hi tathāgataḥ sabbam akusalam jhāpetvā sabbaññu tam patto ti tat pi vacanam micchā
translated: If the Blessed One’s foot was cut by a stone splinter and he had a pain in the side due to a bile-disorder, then it is wrong to say that he attained omniscience after burning up all evil.

original: Natthi, bhante, vinā kammena vedayitaṁ, sabbaṁ taṁ vedayitaṁ kammamūlakaṁ, taṁ kammeneva vedayati, ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho tavānuppatto, so tayā nibbāhitabbo”ti.
analyzed: natthi bhante vinā kammena vedayita sabbam tam vedayitam kamma mūlaka tam kammena iva vedayati ayam pi ubhatas koṭikaḥ pañho tava anuppattaḥ saḥ tayā nibbāhitabbaḥ iti
translated: “Venerable sir, there is no feeling without an action. All feeling has an action as its root. One feels through an action. This is a double-pronged question. Put it to the test.”

original: “Na hi, mahārāja, sabbaṁ taṁ vedayitaṁ kammamūlakaṁ.
analyzed: na hi mahā rāja sabbam tam vedayitam kamma mūlaka
translated: “Great king, not all feeling has an action as its root.

original: Aṭṭhahi, mahārāja, kāraṇehi vedayitāni uppajjanti, yehi kāraṇehi puthū sattā vedanā vediyanti.
analyzed: aṭṭhahi mahā rāja kāraṇehi vedayitāni uppajjanti yehi kāraṇehi puthū sattāḥ vedanāḥ vediyanti
translated: There are eight reasons for the arising of feelings, for the occurrence of various feelings in many different beings.

original: Katamehi aṭṭhahi?
analyzed: katamehi aṭṭhahi
translated: What are the eight?

original: Vātasamuṭṭhānānipi kho, mahārāja, idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti,
analyzed: vāta samuṭṭhānāni pi kho mahā rāja idha ekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti
translated: Great king, some feelings arise from wind,

original: pittasamuṭṭhānānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…🔽semhasamuṭṭhānānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…🔽sannipātikānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…🔽utupariṇāmajānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…🔽visamaparihārajānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…🔽opakkamikānipi kho, mahārāja …pe…
analyzed: pitta samuṭṭhānāni pi kho mahā rāja pe  semha samuṭṭhānāni pi kho mahā rāja pe  sannipātikāni pi kho mahā rāja pe  u tu pariṇāma ja anipi khaḥ mahā rāja pe  kho mahā rāja pe  opakkamikāni pi kho mahā rāja pe
translated: “There are feelings, sire, that arise from bile, from phlegm, from wind, from their combination,

original: kammavipākajānipi kho, mahārāja, idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
analyzed: kamma vipāka jāni api kho mahā rāja idha ekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti
translated: from change of climate, from irregular behavior, from the result of kamma,🔽and from a blow.

original: Imehi kho, mahārāja, aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi puthū sattā vedanā vedayanti.
analyzed: imehi kho mahā rāja aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi puthū sattāḥ vedanāḥ vedayanti
translated: These are the eight reasons, sire, why many beings feel feelings.

original: Tattha ye te puggalā ‘satte kammaṁ vibādhatī’ti vadeyyuṁ, te ime puggalā sattakāraṇaṁ paṭibāhanti.
analyzed: tattha ye te puggalā satte kammam vibādhati iti vadeyyu te ime puggalā satta kāraṇam paṭibāhanti
translated: “Herein, sire, those who would say that kamma is the cause of beings, they deny the cause of beings.

original: Tesaṁ taṁ vacanaṁ micchā”ti.
analyzed: tesam tam vacanam
translated: Their statement is wrong.”

original: “Bhante nāgasena, yañca vātikaṁ yañca pittikaṁ yañca semhikaṁ yañca sannipātikaṁ
analyzed: bhante nāgasena yat ca vātikam yat ca pittikam yat ca semhikam yat ca sannipātika
translated: “Revered Nāgasena, those that arise from wind, from bile, from phlegm, from their combination,

original: yañca utupariṇāmajaṁ yañca visamaparihārajaṁ yañca opakkamikaṁ, sabbete kammasamuṭṭhānāyeva,
analyzed: yat ca utu pariṇāma jam yat ca visama parihāra jam yat ca opakkamika sabbe ete kamma samuṭṭhānāya eva
translated: from change of climate, from irregular behavior, from a blow, all these arise from kamma,

original: kammeneva te sabbe sambhavantī”ti.
analyzed: kammena iva te sabbe sambhavanti iti
translated: all these originate from kamma.”🔽“But, sire, if all these feelings arise from kamma, then kamma is the cause of beings.”

original: “Yadi, mahārāja, tepi sabbe kammasamuṭṭhānāva ābādhā bhaveyyuṁ, na tesaṁ koṭṭhāsato lakkhaṇāni bhaveyyuṁ.
analyzed: yadi mahā rāja te api sabbe ābādhāḥ bhaveyyu na tesam koṭṭhāsataḥ lakkhaṇāni bhaveyyu
translated: “If, sire, all these sicknesses were to arise from kamma, their characteristics would be found in the parts of the body.

original: Vāto kho, mahārāja, kuppamāno dasavidhena kuppati sītena uṇhena jighacchāya pipāsāya atibhuttena ṭhānena padhānena ādhāvanena upakkamena kammavipākena.
analyzed: vātaḥ kho mahā rāja kuppamānaḥ dasavidhena kuppati sītena uṇhena jighacchāya pipāsāya ati bhuttena ṭhānena padhānena ādhāvanena upakkamena kamma vipākena
translated: Wind, sire, when it is disturbed, is disturbed in ten ways: by cold, by heat, by hunger, by thirst, by over-eating, by standing, by walking, by over-exertion, by assault, by kamma-result.

original: Tatra ye te nava vidhā, na te atīte, na anāgate, vattamānake bhave uppajjanti, tasmā na vattabbā ‘kammasambhavā sabbā vedanā’ti.
analyzed: tatra ye te nava vidhāḥ na te atīte na anāgate vattamānake bhave uppajjanti tasmā na vattabbā kamma sambhavā sabbā vedanā ati
translated: Of these ten kinds, nine are not found in the past or the future, they arise in the present state of being. Therefore it cannot be said that all feelings arise from kamma.

original: Pittaṁ, mahārāja, kuppamānaṁ tividhena kuppati sītena uṇhena visamabhojanena.
analyzed: pitta mahā rāja kuppamānam tividhena kuppati sītena uṇhena visama bhojanena
translated: When bile, sire, is disturbed, it is disturbed in three ways: by cold, by heat, by unwholesome food.

original: Semhaṁ, mahārāja, kuppamānaṁ tividhena kuppati sītena uṇhena annapānena.
analyzed: semha mahā rāja kuppamānam tividhena kuppati sītena uṇhena anna pānena
translated: Phlegm, sire, when it is disturbed, is disturbed in three ways: by cold, by heat, by food and drink.

original: Yo ca, mahārāja, vāto yañca pittaṁ yañca semhaṁ, tehi tehi kopehi kuppitvā missī hutvā sakaṁ sakaṁ vedanaṁ ākaḍḍhati.
analyzed: yaḥ ca mahā rāja vātaḥ yat ca pittam yat ca semha tehi tehi kopehi kuppitvā missī hutvā sakam sakam vedanam ākaḍḍhati
translated: And, sire, when the wind, the bile and the phlegm are disturbed by these disturbances, they become mixed up and each draws to itself its own feeling.

original: Utupariṇāmajā, mahārāja, vedanā utupariṇāmena uppajjati.🔽Visamaparihārajā vedanā visamaparihārena uppajjati.
analyzed: utu pariṇāma jā mahā rāja vedanā utu pariṇāmena uppajjati  visama parihāra jā vedanā visama parihārena uppajjati
translated: Pain born of change of temperature arises through change of temperature.🔽Pain born of misconduct arises through misconduct.

original: Opakkamikā, mahārāja, vedanā atthi kiriyā, atthi kammavipākā, kammavipākajā vedanā pubbe katena kammena uppajjati.
analyzed: opakkamikā mahā rāja vedanā atthi kiriyā atthi kamma vipākā kamma vipāka jā vedanā pubbe katena kammena uppajjati
translated: Pain born of kamma is of two kinds, I say: there is kamma-born pain, and there is pain that is the result of kamma. Pain born of kamma arises through kamma done in the past.

original: Iti kho, mahārāja, appaṁ kammavipākajaṁ, bahutaraṁ avasesaṁ.
analyzed: iti kho mahā rāja appam kamma vipāka ja bahutaram
translated: Thus, sire, pain born of the result of kamma is little, the rest is of another kind.

original: Tattha bālā ‘sabbaṁ kammavipākajaṁ yevā’ti atidhāvanti.
analyzed: tattha bālā sabbam kamma vipāka jam atidhāvanti
translated: Herein, the ignorant, ordinary man runs to extremes, saying: ‘All is born of the result of kamma.’

original: Taṁ kammaṁ na sakkā vinā buddhañāṇena vavatthānaṁ kātuṁ.
analyzed: tam kammam na sakkā vinā buddha ñāṇena vavatthānam kātu
translated: But that kamma cannot be defined except by the knowledge of a Buddha.

original: Yaṁ pana, mahārāja, bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato, taṁ vedayitaṁ neva vātasamuṭṭhānaṁ,🔽na pittasamuṭṭhānaṁ, na semhasamuṭṭhānaṁ, na sannipātikaṁ, na utupariṇāmajaṁ, na
analyzed: yam pana mahā rāja bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato tam vedayitam na iva vāta samuṭṭhāna  na pitta samuṭṭhāna na semha samuṭṭhāna na sannipātika na utu pariṇāma ja na
translated: But, sire, the pain that the Blessed One felt when his foot was cut by a stone, that pain was not born of wind,🔽nor of bile, nor of phlegm, nor of their combination, nor was it born of change of temperature,

original: visamaparihārajaṁ, na kammavipākajaṁ, opakkamikaṁyeva.
analyzed: visama parihāra ja na kamma vipāka ja opakkamikayā iva
translated: nor of misconduct, nor of the result of kamma, but it was adventitious.

original: Devadatto hi, mahārāja, bahūni jātisatasahassāni tathāgate āghātaṁ bandhi, so tena
analyzed: devadattaḥ hi mahā rāja bahūni jāti sata sahassāni tathāgate āghātam saḥ tena
translated: For, sire, Devadatta for many a hundred thousand births had cherished hatred for the Tathāgata. He

original: āghātena mahatiṁ garuṁ silaṁ gahetvā ‘matthake pātessāmī’ti muñci, athaññe dve selā🔽āgantvā taṁ silaṁ tathāgataṁ asampattaṁyeva sampaṭicchiṁsu, tāsaṁ pahārena papaṭikā🔽bhijjitvā bhagavato pāde patitvā ruhiraṁ uppādesi, kammavipākato vā, mahārāja, bhagavato
analyzed: āghātena mahatim garum silam gahetvā matthake pātessāmi iti muñci athaññe dve selā  āgantvā tam silam tathāgatam a sampattayā iva tāsam pahārena papaṭikā  bhijjitvā bhagavato pāde patitvā ruhiram uppādesi kamma vipākataḥ vā mahā rāja bhagavato
translated: took a great heavy rock and hurled it, saying: ‘I will dash his head in.’ Then two other rocks came and intercepted that rock🔽before it reached the Tathāgata. By the impact of those rocks a splinter broke off

original: esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyato vā, tatuddhaṁ natthaññā vedanā.
analyzed: esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyataḥ vā tatuddham natthaññā vedanā
translated: and fell on the Blessed One’s foot and drew blood. Either, sire, this pain arose in the Blessed One as the result of kamma or it arose as the result of an act. There is no other cause for it.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, khettaduṭṭhatāya vā bījaṁ na sambhavati bījaduṭṭhatāya vā;
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja khetta duṭṭha tāya vā bījam na sambhavati bīja duṭṭha tāya vā
translated: As, sire, a seed will not grow if the soil is bad or if the seed is bad,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, kammavipākato vā bhagavato esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyato vā, tatuddhaṁ natthaññā vedanā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja kamma vipākataḥ vā bhagavataḥ esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyataḥ vā tatuddham natthaññā vedanā
translated: even so, sire, this pain arose in the Blessed One as the result of kamma or as the result of an act. There is no other cause for it.

original: Yathā vā pana, mahārāja, koṭṭhaduṭṭhatāya vā bhojanaṁ visamaṁ pariṇamati āhāraduṭṭhatāya vā;
analyzed: yathā vā pana mahā rāja koṭṭha duṭṭha tāya vā bhojanam visamam pariṇamati āhāra duṭṭha tāya vā
translated: Or, sire, as food becomes indigestible through the fault of the stomach or through the fault of the food,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, kammavipākato vā bhagavato esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyato vā, tatuddhaṁ natthaññā vedanā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja kamma vipākataḥ vā bhagavataḥ esā vedanā nibbattā kiriyataḥ vā tatuddham natthaññā vedanā
translated: even so, sire, this pain of the Exalted One has arisen either as the result of kamma or as the result of a deed, and there is no other pain than this.

original: Api ca, mahārāja, natthi bhagavato kammavipākajā vedanā, natthi visamaparihārajā
analyzed: api ca mahā rāja natthi bhagavato kamma vipāka jā vedanā natthi visama parihāra jā
translated: But, sire, there is no pain of the Exalted One that has arisen as the result of kamma, nor is there any pain that has arisen as the result of misconduct.

original: vedanā, avasesehi samuṭṭhānehi bhagavato vedanā uppajjati, tāya ca pana vedanāya
analyzed: vedanā avasesehi samuṭṭhānehi bhagavataḥ vedanā uppajjati tāya ca pana vedanāya
translated: Pain arises in the Exalted One from other causes, and by that pain

original: na sakkā bhagavantaṁ jīvitā voropetuṁ.
analyzed: na sakkā bhagavantam jīvitā voropetu
translated: it is not possible to deprive the Exalted One of life.

original: Nipatanti, mahārāja, imasmiṁ cātumahābhūtike kāye iṭṭhāniṭṭhā subhāsubhavedanā.
analyzed: nipatanti mahā rāja imasmin cātumahābhūtike kāye iṭṭha aniṭṭhā subha asubha vedanā
translated: Painful and pleasant feelings, sire, fall upon this body made up of the four great primaries.

original: Idha, mahārāja, ākāse khitto leḍḍu mahāpathaviyā nipatati, api nu kho so, mahārāja, leḍḍu pubbe katena mahāpathaviyā nipatī”ti?
analyzed: idha mahā rāja ākāse khittaḥ leḍḍu mahā pathaviyāḥ nipatati api nu kho saḥ mahā rāja leḍḍu pubbe katena mahā pathaviyāḥ nipati iti
translated: Suppose, sire, a clod is thrown into the air, it falls on the great earth. Now, sire, does that clod fall on the great earth because of a deed done in the past?”

original: “Na hi, bhante, natthi so, bhante, hetu mahāpathaviyā, yena hetunā mahāpathavī kusalākusalavipākaṁ
analyzed: na hi bhante natthi saḥ bhante hetu mahā pathaviyāḥ yena hetunā mahā pathavī kusala akusala vipāka
translated: “No, revered sir, there is no reason for the great earth, sire, because of which the great earth would be the result of good or bad deeds,

original: paṭisaṁvedeyya, paccuppannena, bhante, akammakena hetunā so leḍḍu mahāpathaviyaṁ nipatati”.
analyzed: paccuppannena bhante akammakena hetunā saḥ leḍḍu mahā pathaviyam nipatati
translated: would feel it, because of present action, the clod fell on the great earth.”

original: “Yathā, mahārāja, mahāpathavī, evaṁ tathāgato daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja mahā pathavī evam tathāgataḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: “As, sire, is the great earth, so should the Tathāgata be seen.

original: Yathā leḍḍu pubbe akatena mahāpathaviyaṁ nipatati;
analyzed: yathā leḍḍu pubbe a katena mahā pathaviyam nipatati
translated: As the clod fell on the great earth because of previous action,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, tathāgatassa pubbe akatena sā sakalikā pāde nipatitā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja tathāgatassa pubbe akatena sā sakalikā pāde nipatitā
translated: even so, sire, did that splinter fall on the Tathāgata’s foot because of previous action.

original: Idha pana, mahārāja, manussā mahāpathaviṁ bhindanti ca khaṇanti ca, api nu kho, mahārāja, te manussā pubbe katena mahāpathaviṁ bhindanti ca khaṇanti cā”ti?
analyzed: idha pana mahā rāja manussāḥ mahā pathavim bhindanti ca khaṇanti ca api nu kho mahā rāja te manussāḥ pubbe katena mahā pathavim bhindanti ca khaṇanti ca ati
translated: But, sire, when men dig and delve the great earth, is it because of previous action that those men dig and delve the great earth?”

original: “Na hi, bhante”ti.
analyzed: na hi bhantā iti
translated: “No, revered sir.”

original: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yā sā sakalikā bhagavato pāde nipatitā, na sā sakalikā pubbe katena bhagavato pāde nipatitā.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja yā sā sakalikā bhagavataḥ pāde nipatitā na sā sakalikā pubbe katena bhagavataḥ pāde nipatitā
translated: “Even so, sire, that splinter which fell on the Blessed One’s foot did not fall on the Blessed One’s foot because of previous action.

original: Yopi, mahārāja, bhagavato lohitapakkhandikābādho uppanno, sopi ābādho na pubbe katena
analyzed: yaḥ api mahā rāja bhagavataḥ lohitapakkhandika ābādhaḥ uppannaḥ saḥ api ābādhaḥ na pubbe katena
translated: And, sire, the Blessed One’s affliction of a blood-dysentery, that affliction did not arise because of previous action.

original: uppanno, sannipātikeneva uppanno, ye keci, mahārāja, bhagavato kāyikā ābādhā uppannā,
analyzed: uppannaḥ sannipātikena iva uppannaḥ ye keci mahā rāja bhagavataḥ kāyikāḥ ābādhāḥ uppannā
translated: and arose through a combination of the three. Whatever bodily ailments arose in the Blessed One,

original: na te kammābhinibbattā, channaṁ etesaṁ samuṭṭhānānaṁ aññatarato nibbattā.
analyzed: na te kamma abhinibbattā channam etesam samuṭṭhānānam aññataratas nibbattā
translated: they did not arise through kamma, but arose through one of these six causes.

original: Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā devātidevena saṁyuttanikāyavaralañchake moḷiyasīvake veyyākaraṇe—
